facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 104 to 107 of 1961 arise out of execution proceedings in four different suits.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 104 to 107 of 1961. Appeals from the judgment and order dated July 5, 1956, of the Madras High Court in Appeal against order No. 480, 454, 478 and 479 of 1954 respectively. V. Viswanatha Sastri and R. Gopalakrishnan, for the appellant. N. Rajagopal Sastri and M. S. Narasimhan, for respondent No. 1. 1963. March 7. The judgment of the Court was delivered by MUDHOLKAR J.--This appeal and civil appeals Nos. 104, 106 and 107 of 1961 arise out of execution proceedings in four different suits but as they involve a companymon question they were heard together by the High Court and by us.

facts.text: Appeals from the judgment and order dated July 5, 1956, of the Madras High Court in Appeal against order No. 480, 454, 478 and 479 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and order dated July 5, 1956, of the Madras High Court in Appeal against order No. 480, 454, 478 and 479 of 1954 respectively. V. Viswanatha Sastri and R. Gopalakrishnan, for the appellant. N. Rajagopal Sastri and M. S. Narasimhan, for respondent No. 1. 1963. March 7. The judgment of the Court was delivered by MUDHOLKAR J.--This appeal and civil appeals Nos. 104, 106 and 107 of 1961 arise out of execution proceedings in four different suits but as they involve a companymon question they were heard together by the High Court and by us. That ques- tion is whether the execution applications out of which these appeals arise are within time.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on March 7, 1963 by MUDHOLKAR J.

anchor.surface_text: 1963. March 7. The judgment of the Court was delivered by MUDHOLKAR J.--This appeal and civil appeals Nos. 104, 106 and 107 of 1961 arise out of execution proceedings in four different suits but as they involve a companymon question they were heard together by the High Court and by us. That ques- tion is whether the execution applications out of which these appeals arise are within time. We propose to treat C. A. No. 105 of 1961 as a typical case.

facts.text: In O. S. 46 of 1943, Ramanathan Chettiar instituted a suit against Venkatachalam Chettiar and his son for recovery of Rs. 10,285 due on promissory note dated November 20, 1942 with interest.

anchor.surface_text: The relevant facts thereof are briefly these In O. S. 46 of 1943 one Ramanathan Chettiar instituted a suit against one Venkatachalam Chettiar in the companyrt of the Subordinate Judge of Devakottai, for the recovery of a sum of Rs. 10,285/- due on promisory numbere dated November 20, 1942 with interest thereon. He eventually obtained a decree for the full claim. In so far as the second defendant is companycerned, he was made liable for the decrctal amount to the extent of this interest in the joint family property of himself and his father.

facts.text: Plaintiff obtained a decree for the full claim; second defendant liable to extent of his interest in joint family property.

anchor.surface_text: He eventually obtained a decree for the full claim. In so far as the second defendant is companycerned, he was made liable for the decrctal amount to the extent of this interest in the joint family property of himself and his father. The plaintiff assigned the decree in favour of Chidambaram Chettiar, who is the appellant in A. 105 of 1961. He filed an execution application but the execution proceedings companymenced by him proved infructuous because the first defendant was adjudicated an insolvent on February 27, 1945.

facts.text: Decree assigned to Chidambaram Chettiar, appellant in CA 105 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff assigned the decree in favour of Chidambaram Chettiar, who is the appellant in A. 105 of 1961. He filed an execution application but the execution proceedings companymenced by him proved infructuous because the first defendant was adjudicated an insolvent on February 27, 1945. On September 9, 1946 a companyposition of the debts due from the insolvent and his son, the second defendant. was arrived at.

facts.text: First defendant adjudicated insolvent on February 27, 1945.

anchor.surface_text: He filed an execution application but the execution proceedings companymenced by him proved infructuous because the first defendant was adjudicated an insolvent on February 27, 1945.

facts.text: Composition of debts arrived at on September 9, 1946; second defendant party to deed.

anchor.surface_text: On September 9, 1946 a companyposition of the debts due from the insolvent and his son, the second defendant. was arrived at. To the deed of companyposition the second defendant was also a party though he was number adjudicated an insolvent.

facts.text: Creditors agreed to take 40% of dues under composition.

anchor.surface_text: Under that deed the creditors, including the four appellants before us, agreed to take 40 of the dues, except one creditor who was to be paid a little more.

facts.text: Entire property of defendants in India and Burma vested in four trustees: first defendant, Chidambaram Chettiar, Krishnappa Chettiar, and outsider.

anchor.surface_text: The defendants, it may be mentioned, bad extensive money-lending business in Burma and the bulk of their property was situate in that companyntry. Under the companyposition arrangement the entire property of the defendants, both in India and in Burma was to vest in four trustees, one of whom was the insolvent, that is, the first defendant to the suit. Two of the trustees were the present appellants, Chidambaram Chettiar and Krishnappa Chettiar, appellant in C. A. 104 of 1961. The fourth trustee was an outsider.

facts.text: Total indebtedness Rs. 2,16,077/4/8 reduced to Rs. 86,430-13-3 under arrangement.

anchor.surface_text: The total indebtedness of the defendants, as ascertained on the date on which the companyposition was effected, was Rs. 2,16,077/4/8/- but it was reduced under the arrangement to Rs. 86,430-13-3.

facts.text: Payment of reduced amount by trustees within four years from April 14, 1947, extendable by first two trustees.

anchor.surface_text: The deed provides for the payment of the reduced amount by the trustees to different creditors from the income of the properties or by sale, or mortgage of those properties within four years from April 14, 1947. The deed further provides for the extension of this time limit according to exigencies and necessity at the discretion of the first two trustees i.e., the first defendant and the appellant Chidambaram Chettiar.

facts.text: Insolvency court accepted composition scheme and annulled adjudication on December 19, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: The companyposition scheme was accepted by the insolvency Court and the adjudication of the first defendant as insolvent was annulled by the companyrt on December 19, 1946.

facts.text: Only very little realized from Burma assets within four years due to political changes; trustees did not extend time.

anchor.surface_text: Due to political changes in Burma only very little was realised out of the Burma assets within the period of four years prescribed in the companyposition deed. The trustees who were empowered to extend the time did number extend it.

facts.text: In O.S. No. 46 of 1943, last execution application EP No. 109 of 1946 dismissed on September 19, 1946; next EP No. 117 of 1952 filed on June 13, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: In O. S. No. 46 of 1943 the last execution application was dismissed on September 19, 1946  E. P. No. 109 of 1946 . No execution petition was filed thereafter till the present petition  E. P. No. 117 of 1952 . This was filed on June 13, 1952.

facts.text: Dividend of 10% paid to appellant on August 10, 1949, Rs. 562-4-0.

anchor.surface_text: The trustees were able to realise some of the assets of the defendants in Burma and to pay a dividend of 10 per cent to the creditors. I was paid a sum of Rs. 562-4-0 by way of dividend for this decree on August 10, 1949.

facts.text: Notice issued by second defendant on April 19, 1949 to trustees.

anchor.surface_text: In respect thereof a numberice was issued by the 2nd defendant on April 19, 1949 to myself and A. K. Krishnappa Chettiar aforesaid wherein there is an acknowledgment of liability in respect of the several debts mentioned in the said companyposition.

facts.text: First defendant re-adjudicated insolvent on August 3, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: because in insolvency petition No. 87 of 1951 filed by some of the creditors the first defendant, was readjudicated an insolvent by the companyrt on August 3, 1954.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge held execution applications within time; High Court held barred by time.

anchor.surface_text: The Subordinate judge, before whom the execution applica- tions were filed, upheld this companytention and held that the execution applications were within time. ... The High Court, however, disagreed with the Subordinate judge on both the grounds and holding that the execution petitions were barred by time allowed the appeals.

facts.text: Supreme Court upholds High Court decision and dismisses appeals.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances we must hold that this letter does number extend the period of limitation. For these reasons we uphold the decision of the High Court and dismiss each of these appeals with companyts.

issues.text: whether the execution applications out of which these appeals arise are within time

anchor.surface_text: That question is whether the execution applications out of which these appeals arise are within time. We propose to treat C. A. No. 105 of 1961 as a typical case.

issues.text: whether the principle underlying s. 15(1) of the Limitation Act is applicable to a case of this kind such that the period under the composition scheme is excluded in computing limitation for execution applications

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Viswanatha Sastri, who appears for the appellants in these appeals, has raised only two contentions. The first is that the principle underlying s. 15 1 of the Limitation Act is applicable to a case of this kind and that, therefore, the execution applications are within time.

issues.text: whether the letter dated April 19, 1949, written by the second defendant to the trustees operates as an acknowledgment of liability under s. 19 of the Limitation Act

anchor.surface_text: under s. 19 of the Limitation Act and, therefore, saves the limitation in respect of all the execution applications except the one out of which C. A. No. 104 of 1961 arises.

issues.text: whether the composition arrangement operated as an adjustment of the decree under O. XXI, r. 2, C.P.C. precluding execution for the four-year period and whether it could be certified even now

anchor.surface_text: under 0. XXI, r. 2, C. P. C. within the time permitted by law, it could be certified even now at the instance of the decree-holder

arguments.claim: The principle underlying s. 15(1) of the Limitation Act is applicable, excluding the four-year period of the composition scheme from computing limitation for execution applications

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Viswanatha Sastri, who appears for the appellants in these appeals, has raised only two contentions. The first is that the principle underlying s. 15  1  of the Limitation Act is applicable to a case of this kind and that, therefore, the execution applications are within time. The second is that at any rate the letter dated April 19, 1949, written by the second defendant to the trustees operates as an acknowledgment of liability under s. 19 of the Limitation Act and, therefore, saves the limitation in respect of all the execution applications except the one out of which C. A. No. 104 of 1961 arises. According to Mr. Sastri the composition of a decretal debt does not amount to an adjustment or satisfaction of a decree until the acts required to be done thereunder have been performed.

arguments.claim: s.15(1) applies only where execution stayed by injunction or order; composition not a stay; second defendant not party to insolvency

anchor.surface_text: Section 15  1  of the Limitation Act runs thus 15  1  In computing the period of limi- tation prescribed for any suit or application for the execution of a decree, the institution or execution of which has been stayed by injunction or order, the time of the continuance of the injunction or order, the day on which it was issued or made, and the day on which it was withdrawn, shall be excluded. It is clear from its terms that it is restricted in its application to a case where the execution of a decree has been stayed by an injunction or an order.

arguments.claim: Limitation Act is exhaustive code; provisions cannot be extended by analogy

anchor.surface_text: The Limitation Act is a consolidating and amending statute relating to the limitation of suits, appeals and certain types of applications to courts and must, therefore, be regarded as an exhaustive Code.

arguments.claim: Letter admits jural relationship of debtor-creditor under decrees

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sastri contends that this letter contains a definite admission of the jural relationship between the defendant on the one hand and the creditors on the other i. e., the relationship of creditor and debtor and, therefore, this is an admission of liability under the decrees.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: hould be inferred., or where a statement was made clearly without intending to admit the existence of jural relationship such intention companyld be f

arguments.court_reasoning: Liability under composition vested in trustees; defendant refers to trustees' liability, not own under decree

holdings.text: Section 15(1) of the Limitation Act is restricted in its application to a case where the execution of a decree has been stayed by an injunction or an order.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear from its terms that it is restricted in its application to a case where the execution of a decree has been stayed by an injunction or an order. By no stretch of imagi

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of the section's plain language limits it to explicit stays by injunction or order.

holdings.text: The acceptance by the insolvency court of the composition did not operate as a stay of execution of the decrees or as an injunction under Section 15(1).

anchor.surface_text: By no stretch of imagination can it be said that the acceptance by the insolvency court of the composition operated as a stay of execution of the decrees for the period

holdings.reasoning_summary: No imagination stretches the composition acceptance to equate with statutory stay or injunction; second defendant not party to insolvency.

holdings.text: The second defendant was not a party to the insolvency proceedings and could not have been entitled to the benefit of the order accepting the scheme.

anchor.surface_text: Further, the second defendant was not a party to the insolvency proceedings and could, therefore, not have been entitled to the benefit of the order of the court

holdings.reasoning_summary: Factual distinction: second defendant not adjudicated insolvent, not bound by insolvency court order as party.

holdings.text: The Limitation Act is an exhaustive code and its provisions cannot be extended by analogy or implication to suspend limitation outside their purview.

anchor.surface_text: The Limitation Act is a consolidating and amending statute relating to the limitation of suits, appeals and certain types of applications to courts and must, therefore,

holdings.reasoning_summary: As procedural law, applies only expressly or by necessary implication; no general suspension principle.

holdings.text: We are unable to accept the first argument that principles underlying s.15(1) apply to exclude the composition period.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, unable to accept the first argument of Mr. Sastri.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Combination of textual limits, factual distinctions, exhaustive code doctrine reject analogy.

holdings.text: The letter dated April 19, 1949, refers to the trustees' liability under the composition deed, not the defendant's personal liability under the decree.

anchor.surface_text: What the defendant No. 2 has referred to is the liability of the Trustees arising under the terms of the deed of composition and could be enforced only against them.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinct liabilities: personal under decree vs. trustees' under trust; letter demands from trustees maintenance and dividends.

holdings.text: To refer to a liability resting on someone else is not to acknowledge one's own liability within the meaning of s.19.

anchor.surface_text: To refer to a liability resting on someone else is not to acknowledge ones own liability within the meaning of the word in s. 19.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Acknowledgment requires admitting own subsisting jural relationship; here, references trustees only.

holdings.text: The defendant No. 2 has not even indirectly referred to the decree much less to the liability arising under any of them.

anchor.surface_text: The defendant No. 2 has not even indirectly referred to the decree much less to the liability arising under any of them.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No mention of decree or personal liability in letter.

holdings.text: This letter does not extend the period of limitation under s.19.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances we must hold that this letter does not extend the period of limitation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fails to admit own liability under decree as required by s.19 and Shapoor Mazda precedent.

holdings.text: The execution applications are barred by time; we uphold the High Court decision and dismiss the appeals.

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons we uphold the decision of the High Court and dismiss each of these appeals with costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejection of both contentions on limitation extension leads to bar by time.

anchor.surface_text: Relying upon the decision of this Court in Khan Bahadur Shapoor Freedom Mazda v. Durga Prosad Chamria 1 , he says that the essential requirement for sustaining a plea of acknowledgment under s. 19 of the Limitation Act is that the statement on which it is sought to be founded must relate to a subsisting liability,

precedents.cited_proposition: acknowledgment under s.19 requires statement relating to subsisting liability and jural relationship of debtor-creditor, need not specify exact nature
precedents.cited_holding: statement indicating jural relationship and intention to admit it suffices for acknowledgment even if exact liability not specified
